intro: Vaccaria vulgaris, commonly known as mouse-ear chickweed, is a low-growing annual plant characterized by its small, fleshy leaves and clusters of tiny white flowers. It belongs to the family Cucurbitaceae, which includes cucumbers and melons, though it is not related to them botanically. The plant thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in gardens, fields, and along roadsides. Its seeds are dispersed by wind, and it has a short life cycle, completing its growth within a single growing season. The leaves are often covered in fine hairs, giving the plant a distinctive appearance.
